a type 2 error would be if we decided that the amount of rainfall was equal to 40 when it was more than 40

The example: The poll of whether people were male or not male and if they attended sporting events at Penn State.  I will be going along with this as if the question was do male students attend sporting events more than females who attend sporting events. P1 is male and P2 is female
Null Hypothesis: P1 = P2 (They are the same)
Alternative Hypothesis: P1 > P2 (Males attend more than female)
Type 1 Error: I reject the null hypothesis stating that males attend sporting events more than females, when in reality they have the same amount of attendance.
Type 2 Erorr: I fail to reject the null hypothesis stating that males attend the same amount of sporting events as females, when in reality males attend more.
Potential Consequences: A potential consequence with a type 1 error is that a female could see the false information that more males attend than females and feel discouraged to go from the lack of other females going. A potential consequence with a type 2 error is that there could be a game at the sporting event where males and females have to split into teams and the teams will be heavily catered to the large amount of boys when they thought there was an equal amount on each side.

Is there an association between year and how many times you visit facebook? The null hypothesis would be there is no association between year and frequency of visiting facebook. The alternative hypothesis is there is an association between year and frequency of visiting facebook. A type 1 error occurs when the null is rejected when in reality the null is true. In this context the type 1 error would be they reject the null when there is indeed no association. Whereas a type 2 error occurs when the null is not rejected and in reality the null is false, so in this context the null is not rejected but there is an association.

Null Hypothesis: The individual is not infected.
Alternative Hypothesis: The individual is infected.
In this context, a type 1 error would occur if the test incorrectly indicates that the person is infected when, in fact, they are not.
A type 2 error would happen if the test fails to detect the infection when the person is actually infected. Consequences could be unnecessary treatments and emotional distress for individuals who are wrongly identified as positive for the type 1 error. Or delayed or missed treatment, allowing the disease to progress, potentially causing harm to the individual and increasing the risk of transmission to others for the type 2 error.

Does the proportion of people who support gun control differ between males and females. 

Null: p1-p2 = 0. Alternative: p1-p2 does not = 0.

Type 1 error: reject null when in reality null is true. This means you would conclude that there is a convincing difference in the proportion of people who support gun control between males and females when in reality there is not.

Type 2 error: fail to reject null when in reality the null is false. This means you would conclude that there is not a convincing difference in the proportion of people who support gun control between males and females when in reality there is a difference. 

The consequences of a type 1 error could be that politicians would direct funding and campaigning to either males or females more heavily if they want to change gun control legislation and this would be a misallocation of funding and resources and wasted time on a specific issue when there is no difference. 

The consequences of a type 2 error lead to a missed opportunity for politicians and policymakers to appeal to a specific gender or demographic. If there is a genuine difference in opinion then this would be a missed chance to appeal to a specific group for votes or support by believing that there is no difference.

Example: Consider the law system where a person is innocent until they are proven guilty. 

-H0: person is innocent   Ha: Guilty

- A type 1 error would occur is we convict an innocent person.

-A type 2 error would occur if we release a guilty person.

In each situation, there are consequences with the decisions. If you convict an innocent person, it is unfair to them and you are ruining their life. However, if you release a guilty person, they are not getting the time they deserve for their wrongdoings and it is dangerous to society.

An example from lab is flipping a coin. The null hypothesis would be that there is equal chance of flipping heads and tails , or p-hat1=p-hat2. The alternative hypothesis would be that there is a greater likelihood of flipping heads versus tails, or p-hat1>p-hat 2. A type 1 error means we have created a false positive. In other words, we concluded there was a difference when there was not. In this scenario, a type 1 error would occur if we flipped a lot of heads when in reality there was an equal amount. A type 2 error is called a false negative in which we conclude there is no difference when there is. In this case, a type 2 error would occur if we conclude there is an equal amount of heads when in reality there are more. In this scenario there would not be as harmful implications as this is a mundane situation. However, if a type 1 error occurs, it could mean that a drug/substance would be given to a lot of people assuming it does not have harmful side effects when it does. Taking the drug example again, a type 2 error could be harmful if the drug is not given because it does not seem to be more beneficial than what is already available when in reality it would be.

An example we discussed in the lab is about testing for a new drug. The null hypothesis is that the new drug does not work and is not significantly better than the current drug. The alternative hypothesis is that the new drug is significantly better than the current drug and has better health benefits. 
The type 1 error would be that you believe that the drug has significant health benefits than the current drug, but the new drug truly does not have better health benefits. 
Type 2 error would be that you believe that the drug does not have significant health benefits when truly it does have significant health benefits than the older drug. 
The potential consequences associated with a type 1 error would be that you give the million of people the new drug saying that it is better for your health and it causes the population to suffer new side effects that are worse for your health. For type 2 errors you don't give million of people the new drug thinking it is not better when in fact it can help the population that would benefit from the new drug.

type 1= null was false but we assumed it to be true
type 2= null was true but we assumed it to be false

Example: When flipping a coin, will it land on tails more than heads?
Null: P=0.5, Alternative: P>0.5
Type 1 error: We rejected the null hypothesis and found that the coin will land on tails more often when really we had a false positive and the results were actually just due to chance and the coin is not more likely to land on tails than heads.
Type 2 error: We failed to reject the null hypothesis and found that the results were just due to chance, when really that coin does land on tails more often than heads and we missed that there is actually something going on in the data.
Consequences: Type 1 errors can be dangerous if we are testing drugs because people may be prescribed them to help, but they aren't actually doing anything. Type 2 errors can be dangerous because we could miss the chance to give people something that will help their condition because we did not have a significant result.

When looking at if a medicine if actually beneficial or not it is very important not to fall for these errors. Perhaps if our alternative hypothesis shows that patients using this new medicine have an increase in positive health benefits compared to those who are given a placebo, and our null was that there was no difference in health benefits. A type one error would occur if the researchers did not find any benefits when there was in fact positive benefits. A type two error would occur if there was an association found when in fact there is no real association. Making these errors have grave implications since in both instances real medicine is either rejected or replaced by a placebo more or less.

The example that I chose from class involved the effectiveness of a new blood thinning drug, in which it was tested in a double-blind experiment against the current (old) drug. The null hypothesis is mu new = mu old, and the alternative hypothesis is mu new < mu old. A type 1 error in this situation would mean that there is evidence that the new drug is better than the old one, when it actually is not. A type 2 error in this situation would mean that there is not enough evidence to say the new drug is better when it actually is. For the type 1 error, the consequences would be worse because we would have people take the new drug thinking it's more effective, when in reality it isn't. The consequences of the type 2 error would be that people would continue taking the old drug when the new drug is actually better. Here, people won't directly be harmed because although the new drug is more effective, they are still taking the old drug that works fine.

Alternative hypothesis is the one that states there will be a change due to a treatment. And the null states that there will be no change due to the treatment. Basically saying that the treatment has no effect. Type one error is when you reject the null when you are meant to fail to reject. An example of this in context would be a positive pregnancy test when the person is not actually pregnant. Type two error is when you fail to reject the null when you were meant to reject it. An example is a false pregnancy test when the person is actually pregnant.  Type one can be misleading because it may lead to people believing that whatever the treatment was worked when it actually didn't. And type two can lead to people not knowing that whatever treatment they did worked.

Null hypothesis: The new medicine has no effect in preventing the virus.

Alternative hypothesis: The new medicine is effective in preventing the virus.

Type 1 error: This occurs if we mistakenly conclude that the new medicine is effective when, in reality, it doesn't work against the virus. 

Type 2 error: This happens if we mistakenly conclude that the new medicine is not effective when, in fact, it does work.

Type 1 error consequences: It could be dangerous to give a sick person a medicine that doesn't work.

Type 2 error consequences: You are wasting the opportunity to use a new medicine that prevents the virus.

-Null Hypothesis: The new drug has no effect or is no better than the existing treatment.
-Alternative Hypothesis: The new drug is effective and produces a significant improvement over the existing treatment.
-In this context, a Type 1 error occurs if the statistical test incorrectly rejects the null hypothesis. This would mean concluding that the new drug is effective when, in reality, it has no significant impact.
-A Type 2 error occurs if the statistical test fails to reject the null hypothesis when it is false. In this case, it means not recognizing the efficacy of the new drug when it actually has positive effects. The consequence of a Type 2 error could be the rejection of a potentially beneficial drug, resulting in missed opportunities for improved treatments and patient outcomes.
-consequence of error type 1: May lead to wasted resources, financial losses, and potential harm to patients who might be exposed to a less effective or even harmful treatment.
-consequence of error type 2:Could result in missed opportunities for medical advancements, leading to prolonged use of less effective treatments and delaying potential benefits for patients.

describe the null and alternative hypotheses for the chosen example; testing a new drug with potentially dangerous side effects to see it it’s significantly better than the drug currently in use. if found to be better it will be prescribed to millions of people. Null Hypothesis (H0): The new drug is not significantly better than the current drug.
- Symbolically, we can represent this as H0: μnew = μcurrent, where μnew represents the population mean effectiveness of the new drug and μcurrent represents the population mean effectiveness of the current drug.

Alternative Hypothesis (Ha): The new drug is significantly better than the current drug.
- Symbolically, we can represent this as Ha: μnew > μcurrent, indicating that the population mean effectiveness of the new drug is greater than that of the current drug.

If the new drug is found to be significantly better, it could potentially be prescribed to millions of people.


explain the meaning of a type 1 error (i.e., a "false positive") in the chosen context; 
Type 1 Error (False Positive):
A Type 1 error occurs when we reject the null hypothesis (H0) when it is actually true. In other words, we conclude that the new drug is significantly better than the current drug when, in reality, there is no significant difference. This can lead to the incorrect adoption of the new drug, thinking it is superior, when it may not be. this could be dangerous and life threatening for those who may take the new drug thinking it’s helping when in reality it could be hurting them significantly. 

explain the meaning of a type 2 error (i.e., a "false negative") in the chosen context; 

Type 2 Error (False Negative):
A Type 2 error occurs when we fail to reject the null hypothesis (H0) when it is actually false. In this case, it would mean that we conclude that the new drug is not significantly better than the current drug, when in reality, it is. This can lead to the missed opportunity of providing a potentially more effective treatment to patients.
 

describe the potential consequences associated with each type of wrong decision (i.e., type 1 or type 2 error). 
Consequence of Type 1 Error: this could be widespread prescription of this new drug based on a false belief that it is better than the old one.this could result in dangerous side effects and an even greater risk for patients.
Consequence of Type 2 Error:
The potential consequence of a Type 2 error would be the continued use of the current drug, even though the new drug could offer better effectiveness. This could result in patients not receiving the potential benefits of the new drug and potentially prolonging their suffering or not achieving optimal treatment outcomes.

Chosen example: We are interested in testing to see if there is evidence that the population mean for mathematics placement exam scores is greater than 25.
H0: mu=25
Ha: mu>25

The null hypothesis states that if there is no difference, the population mean will equal 25. The alternative hypothesis states that if there is a difference, the population mean will be greater than 25. 

In this case type 1 error would be rejecting that the population mean is equal to 25 and saying it was greater than 25, when you should've failed to reject that it was equal to 25.

In this case type 2 error would be failing to reject that the population mean is equal to 25 when you should've rejected that and said that it was greater than 25. 

The potential consequences with type 1 error is that the researcher will have made an incorrect conclusion. The potential consequences with type 2 error is that the researcher missed an opportunity to learn more about the test scores.

Let's consider a medical example where a new diagnostic test for a rare disease is being evaluated.

1. **Hypotheses:**
   - **Null Hypothesis (H₀):** The new diagnostic test is not effective in correctly identifying individuals with the disease.
   - **Alternative Hypothesis (H₁):** The new diagnostic test is effective in correctly identifying individuals with the disease.

2. **Type I Error (False Positive):**
   - **Meaning:** A Type I error in this context would occur if the test incorrectly indicates a patient has the disease (false positive), leading to unnecessary stress, further tests, and potentially treatments for a condition they don't have.
   - **Consequences:** Patients may endure unnecessary medical procedures, incur additional costs, and experience psychological distress due to a misdiagnosis.

3. **Type II Error (False Negative):**
   - **Meaning:** A Type II error would happen if the test fails to identify a patient who actually has the disease (false negative), potentially delaying necessary treatment.
   - **Consequences:** Individuals with the disease may not receive timely medical intervention, leading to progression of the illness and potentially more severe outcomes.

In summary, a Type I error could result in unnecessary interventions and costs, while a Type II error could lead to delayed or missed treatments, impacting patient outcomes. The balance between these errors is crucial in evaluating the effectiveness and reliability of the diagnostic test.

Example: You symptons are moderate, you decide to get tested for COVID-19. the idea that you don't have COVID-19 is the null hypothesis. 

With the null answer is true but you reject it, a type 1 error happens, indicating that although the test results indicate you have COVID-19, you actually don't. 

When you fail to reject a null value that is actually false-- that is, when the test results indicate that you do not have COVID-19 while in fact you do -- you are comminting a type 2 error.

Alternative hypothesis: the number of people who relapsed after taking desipramine is less than the number that replaced after taking lithium
type 1 error: we say that the number of people who took desipramine then relapsed was less than the number of people who took lithium then relapsed when in reality the number of people who relapsed after taking despiramine and lithium was the same
type 2 error: we say that the number of people who relapsed after taking despiramine and lithium was the same when in reality the number of people who relapsed after taking desipramine is less than the number that replaced after taking lithium

Scenario: diagnostic testing for a rare disease

Null Hypotheses: The diagnostic test does not accurately detect the presence of the disease.

Alternative Hypotheses: The diagnostic test does accurately detect the presence of the disease. 

Type 1 error (false positive): The patient does not have the disease but the test falsely indicates that they do. This could result in the patient having to further pay and receive medical attention and testing. 

Type 2 error (false negative): The patient has the disease but the test does not indicate that they do. This could result in the patient not receiving the needed medical attention which would affect their health.

Null Hypothesis (H0): The new drug has a(=) significant effect on reducing blood pressure.

Alternative Hypothesis (Ha): The new drug has no(=/) significant effect on reducing blood pressure.

Type 1 Error (False Positive): A Type 1 error occurs if we reject the null hypothesis when it is actually true. This would mean concluding that the new drug is effective in reducing blood pressure when it actually has no such effect.

Type 2 Error (False Negative): A Type 2 error occurs if we fail to reject the null hypothesis when the alternative is true. In the blood pressure example, this would mean not detecting the actual effectiveness of the drug.

Type 1 Error: Patients may be subjected to unnecessary treatments, incurring additional healthcare costs and possible side effects without gaining the expected benefits.

Type 2 Error: Patients might miss the opportunity for a beneficial treatment, leading to unmanaged health conditions and increased health risks.

I'll base this off of the study we used in a lab about gamers having different sleep patterns than nongamers.

- The null hypothesis is that there is no difference in the average amount of sleep between gamers and non-gamers, while the alternative hypothesis is that gamers have a different average amount of sleep compared to non-gamers.

- A Type 1 error occurs if we incorrectly reject the null hypothesis and conclude that gamers have a different average sleep duration when there really is no difference. This would lead to the false belief that gaming is associated with less sleep, which could lead to unwarranted resources being allocated to solve this nonissue.

- A Type 2 error occurs if we fail to reject the null hypothesis when there actually is a difference in average sleep duration between gamers and non-gamers. This would mean overlooking the issue of reduced sleep in gamers, allowing gamers to continue to get less sleep when this problem could potentially be addressed.

Type 1 error: this occurs when the statistician rejects a null hypothesis that is actually true (false positive) and believes the alternative hypothesis is true 

Type 2 error: this occurs when the statistician does not reject the null hypothesis that is actually false (false negative) and believes that the alternative hypothesis is false. 

A potential consequence with a type 1 error is since you're assuming that your hypothesis is false when it is true it can result in giving out faulty products to the public. A type 1 error occurs when the null hypothesis is rejected even though it is true. In the chosen context, this means concluding that there is a significant effect or relationship when there actually isn't. 
A type 2 error happens when the null hypothesis is accepted even though it is false. In the chosen context, this means failing to detect a significant effect or relationship when it actually exists. 
In the case of a type 1 error, it could lead to necessary actions based on a false belief in the presence of an effect. This could waste resources or cause harm if the actions taken are not justified. 
A type 2 error consequence is the failure to identify a real effect or relationship. This could result in missed opportunities or incorrect conclusions, leading to a lack of action or necessary interventions. It may also hinder progress or hinder the understanding of the subject being analyzed.

Class Example: Desipramine vs Placebo

Null Hypothesis (H0):
H0 for Desipramine: The rate of relapse for individuals using Desipramine is the same as the rate for those on placebo.
H0 for Lithium: The rate of relapse for individuals using Lithium is the same as the rate for those on placebo.

Alternative Hypothesis (H1):
H1 for Desipramine: The rate of relapse for individuals using Desipramine is different from t
H1 for Lithium: The rate of relapse for individuals using Lithium is different from the rate for those on placebo.

In this context, a Type 1 error would occur if the study concludes that Desipramine (or Lithium) is more effective at preventing relapses compared to a placebo when, in reality, there is no significant difference between them. It's a false positive conclusion, indicating a treatment effect when none truly exists.

A Type 2 error would happen if the study fails to detect a significant difference between Desipramine (or Lithium) and a placebo in preventing relapses when there is indeed a genuine difference


Type 1 Error: It might lead to the adoption of Desipramine or Lithium as treatments for preventing relapses among individuals with cocaine addiction when, in fact, they might not be more effective than a placebo. This could result in unnecessary treatment, potential side effects, and unnecessary costs.

Type 2 Error : This error might result in the rejection of Desipramine or Lithium as potentially effective treatments for preventing relapses among individuals with cocaine addiction, even though they could have been beneficial. This could lead to missed opportunities for effective treatments and hinder progress in managing addiction.

Example: Clinical Drug Trial

Null Hypothesis (H0): The new drug has no effect on reducing blood pressure.

Alternative Hypothesis (H1): The new drug is effective in reducing blood pressure.

Type I Error (False Positive):
A Type I error in this context would occur if the study incorrectly concludes that the new drug is effective (rejects the null hypothesis) when, in reality, it has no impact on reducing blood pressure. This could lead to the drug being approved and marketed based on a false claim of effectiveness.

Type II Error (False Negative):
A Type II error would happen if the study fails to detect the effectiveness of the new drug (fails to reject the null hypothesis) when, in fact, it does reduce blood pressure. This could result in the drug not being approved, depriving patients of a potentially beneficial treatment.

Consequences:

Type I Error (False Positive):

Consequence: Patients might be prescribed and use a drug that doesn't actually work, leading to unnecessary expenses and potential side effects.
Ethical Consideration: False claims of effectiveness could erode trust in the pharmaceutical industry and healthcare system.
Type II Error (False Negative):

Consequence: Patients miss out on a drug that could effectively treat their condition, potentially leading to worsened health outcomes.
Ethical Consideration: Denying access to a beneficial treatment raises ethical concerns about the well-being of study participants and future patients.
In both cases, the consequences highlight the importance of carefully controlling Type I and Type II error rates in hypothesis testing, as they directly impact decisions with real-world implications for individuals and public health.

When comparing the GPAs of Apple and Android users, for example, the null hypothesis represents no significant GPA difference, while the alternative hypothesis could suggest Apple users have a higher GPA. A Type 1 error in this situation, or "false positive," may occur if we incorrectly conclude a GPA difference when none exists, leading to misguided assumptions about the correlation between smartphone choice and GPA. On the other hand, a Type 2 error, or "false negative," would happen if we fail to identify an actual GPA difference, meaning we may have overlooked a correlation between smartphone and success. Minimizing both types of errors is essential to conclude accurate and trustworthy results- when either error occurs, our data can be interpreted to suggest that one brand of phone results in a higher GPA than the other (Type 1 error), or, we could suggest that there is not GPA different when in reality there is (Type 2 error). Both of these errors can lead to faulty studies which is why we aim to avoid misleading conclusions.

Errors and potential consequences: 
Type 1 error: A type 1 error can occur when the p-value is smaller than 0.05 leading us to falsely reject the null. In other words, we would reject the null, even though the null is true. For example, approving a new drug that might not have an effect on a person. 

Type II error: A type 2 error can occur when the p-value is greater than 0.05, leading us to favor the null. In other words, we would favor the null, even though it is not true leading to a false negative. For example, approving a new drug that may be actually dangerous.

A null hypothesis states that there is no effect on the population, and the alternative hypothesis states that there is a difference. A type 1 error happens when a statistician rejects a null hypothesis when it is actually true, and a type 2 happens when you do not reject the null hypothesis when the null is true. A type 1 error would be if you have a false positive flu test (you do not have the flu but the test says you do). A type 2 error would be if you have a false negative flu test (you do have the flu but the test says you do not).

One example that we used during a lab questioned if there was a linear association between a football players bench weight, and what round they were drafted in. The null hypothesis would be rho= 0, meaning that there was no association, and the alternative is that rho is not equal to 0, meaning that there is a linear association. A type one error could occur in this situation if we were to reject the null when it was true, meaning that we thought there was an association when there really was not. A type 2 error could occur if we do not reject the null when it is actually false, meaning we believe that there is no relationship between bench weight and draft round when their truly is.

Whether females seek post-grad education at greater rates than males do. The Null is that there is no difference in the rates of seeking postgraduate education between females and males. The alternative is that females do seek postgraduate education at greater rates than males. A Type I error would mean concluding that there is a significant difference in enrollment rates between females and males but there isn't any difference. A Type II error would occur if we do not find a statistically significant difference in enrollment rates between females and males but there is a difference. The consequences would be false information being spread.

a company makes things like toys, and they want to make sure everything is working well during production.

Null Hypothesis: Everything is good, and the toys meet all the required standards.

Alternative Hypothesis : Something is wrong in how they're making the toys, and they don't meet the standards.
Type 1 Error (False Positive):

Meaning: Saying there's a problem when there isn't one.
Consequence: Stopping the production or changing things when it's not needed, costing the company money.
Type 2 Error (False Negative):

Meaning: Missing a real problem in how they're making the toys.
Consequence: Bad toys might end up in stores, and people could be unhappy, causing the company to lose money and trust.

A type 1 error would be rejecting p1-p2=0 based off of our p-value when in reality the null hypothesis is true. A potential consequence of this for an experimental drug would be us sending out a drug with harmful side-effects in hopes that it's significantly better than the previous drug used in order to warrant the side effects but it actually isnt any more effective than the previous drug. Type two is not rejecting a null hypothesis that is false. The consequences of this would be failing to release an experimental drug that is more effective than the current drug in use, holding life saving treatment from people who need it due to poor oversight.

Null and Alternative Hypotheses:
The null hypothesis (H0) is that the new drug has no effect on blood pressure compared to a placebo. The alternative hypothesis (H1) is that the new drug does have an effect on lowering blood pressure compared to a placebo.
Type I Error (False Positive):

A Type I error in this context would occur if the statistical analysis suggests that the new drug is effective in lowering blood pressure when, in fact, it is not. This is a false positive because the analysis indicates a drug effect that does not actually exist.
Type II Error (False Negative):

A Type II error, on the other hand, would happen if the analysis fails to detect a true effect of the drug. In other words, the new drug does lower blood pressure, but the statistical test incorrectly suggests there is no difference from the placebo.
Consequences of Each Type of Error:

Consequences of a Type I Error: If the company concludes that the drug is effective when it is not, they might invest in manufacturing and marketing a drug that does not provide the intended health benefits. Patients may experience side effects without any therapeutic advantage, and resources would be misallocated away from more effective treatments.

Consequences of a Type II Error: If the company wrongly concludes that the drug is not effective, a potentially beneficial medication might not be brought to market, depriving patients of a treatment that could improve their health. Additionally, the company could miss out on the financial benefits of a successful new drug, and further research in a potentially fruitful direction might be abandoned.

1. Null: µ1 = µ2 
Alternative: µ1 > µ2 

Does this new medication result in a higher white blood cell count than the previously used medication? 

2. Type 1 error would be to claim that there is strong evidence to support that the new medicine results in a higher white blood cell count, when there actually is not.

3. Type II error would be failing to claim that there is strong evidence to support that the new medicine results in higher white blood cell count, when it actually does

4. Either error would be bad in this case. A type I error could mean approving a drug that is not more efficient to replace the other, perhaps causing uneccessary financial costs and perhaps dangerous effects to those who switch when they shouldn't have. A type 1 error could be better controlled by using a stronger significance level to determine the outcome of experiments. A type 2 error could mean failing to recognize that a new drug would be more efficient that the currently prescribed one, and this could mean a potential number of individuals are lacking the proper health care they should receive. The likelihood of making a type 2 error can be reduced by increasing the sig. level.

Situation: We are interested in seeing if there is a negative correlation between exam grades and hours spent playing video games.

Null: rho=0 Alt: rho<0

Type 1 error: The null is rejected, meaning that the researcher found significance in an observed value. This means that they claimed there was a negative association between the two variables. In this case, it was an error, where the null, should not have been rejected. This piece of evidence claims there is a negative association between the two variables when in reality they have no association. A potential consequence is that people will think that playing video games affects exam grades in a bad way, which can possibly lead to kids being banned from playing video games for no reason.

Type 2 error: The null failed to be rejected, when in reality it should have been rejected. The observed value showed that playing video games did not have anything to do with test scores when in reality, it negatively impacted it. A consequence from this error could be kids playing video games thinking that it won’t affect their test scores when in reality, it will cause them to decline.

A type one error in this situation would be rejecting that they spend exactly 7 hours on average sleeping per night and a type two error would be failing to reject the null, when in fact they do spend less than 7 hours on average sleeping per night. With the type one error, there could be the consequence of wasted time and resources whereas type two has a consequence of not making a change to something.

"We are testing a new drug with potentially dangerous side effects to see if it is significantly better than the drug currently in use. If it is found to be more effective, it will be prescribed to millions of people." 
The null hypothesis would be that the new drug is not as effective as the current drug.
The alternative hypothesis would be that the new drug works better than the old drug. 
Type I error is that researchers say the drug is better when it actually is not. 
A type II error would be when researchers say that the new drug is not as effective as it actually is and is still telling patients to take the old drug. 
Type I consequences would be that patients are not getting the best possible care. Type II consequences are that patients are not receiving the right medicine.

A type 1 error is when you reject the null hypothesis when it is actually true
A type 2 error is when you fail to reject the null hypothesis when the alternative hypothesis is true

H0: p = 0.3  vs Ha:  p ≠ 0.3.  

If the p-value <0.05, we reject the null hypothesis. If the p-value >0.05, we fail to reject the null hypothesis.

A Type 1 error is when you reject the null and conclude that the alternative hypothesis is true, but you get a false positive. In this context, if we concluded that p ≠ 0.3, but we were wrong.

A Type 2 error is when you fail to reject the null hypothesis and you get a false negative. In this context, if we concluded that p ≠ 0.3, but we were wrong.

Making the mistake of assuming that a condition exists or that a treatment is effective could result in pointless actions or interventions. Frequent Type 1 errors have the potential to damage decision-makers' or the statistical methods' credibility. Due to its undetected nature, a Type 2 error may contribute to the persistence of an issue. A Type 2 error can have major repercussions in industries like healthcare or safety since it may result in the misidentification of a dangerous condition or adverse drug reaction.

One example is testing the effectiveness of a drug versus not taking the drug.
We can test by looking at the proportion of patients who reach remission while on the drug versus not on the drug. 
The null hypothesis would be P1=P2, and the alternative would be P1 > P2 meaning that more patients reach remission on the drug. 
A type 1 error would be rejecting the null and saying there is a difference and the drug is effective, when in reality it is not effective. 
A type 2 error would be not rejecting the null, meaning you say there is no difference and the drug is ineffective, when really there is a difference. 
The consequence of type 1 would be putting a drug on the shelf and people thinking it works, when it does it and potentially causing more harm than good. A type 2 error would remove a potentially life saving drug off the shelf when it really is effective and helps patients.

A false positive can also be described as a false alarm. meaning that something was found to be positive when it was actually negative. Vice versa. An example of a false negative would be testing negative for COVID when you actually do have it.

Whether race is associated with whether you are placed in a control group or treatment group.

Null hypothesis: Race is not associated with being placed in a control or treatment group.
Alternative hypothesis: Race is associated with being placed in a control or treatment group. 

Type I error: Race is not associated with being placed in a control or treatment group, but you reject the null and say that there is an association between race and group placement. 

Type II error: Race is associated with being placed in a control or treatment group, but you accept the null and that there is not an association between race and group placement.

The null hypothesis is that there would be 70 percent who sleep 8 hours or more and the alternative hypothesis is that there would be greater than 70 percent. A type 1 error would occur if we rejected the null hypothesis when there were 70 percent or lower people who slept 8 or more hours. A type 2 error would occur if we failed to reject the null hypothesis when there were more than 70 percent. A type 1 error would result in us believing that more people were getting enough sleep when they actually aren't and a type 2 error would result in us believing that people aren't getting enough sleep when they actually are.

Question: "A survey was conducted in the United Kingdom, where respondents were asked if they had a university degree. One question asked, "In the last 20 years, the proportion of the world population living in extreme poverty has...", and the three choices were provided: 1) "increased" 2) "remained more or less the same" and 3) "decreased". Of the 373 university degree holders 45 responded with the correct answer: decreased; of 639 non-degree respondents, 57 responded with the correct answer. We would like to test if the percent of correct answers is significantly different between degree holders and non-degree holders. 

1. Null and Alternative hypotheses. Ho: p1 = p2 Ha: p1 =/= p2
2. A type I error in this context would mean that we determined that there is a significant difference between the degree holders and non-degree holders responses when in fact there is not.
3. A type II error in this context would that we determined there is no difference between degree holders and non-degree holders when in fact there is.
4. A type I error would have to consequence of this study believing in a different between the two groups that is not there. Those who published the study may suffer in terms of their creditably. A type II error would merely lead to the study not being published and a belief that there is no difference may circulate even though there in fact is one.

"At Beaver Stadium, attendees are permitted to bring in one clear plastic, flat-seamed (not rectangular-bottomed), one-gallon plastic bag (no bigger than 11" x 11" x 0") per person. Policy makers at the stadium are curious about how much attendees are using this provision. At a randomly chosen football game this year, they randomly select 200 ticket holders who have entered the stadium and record their sex, if they have a bag, the size of the bag in gallons and they weigh the bag and record the measurement in pounds (lbs). One of the questions the policy makers want to answer is, "Is there a difference in the proportions of males and females who bring a bag?"

In this scenario, the null hypothesis is p1-p2=0, and the alternative hypothesis is p1-p2 not = 0. A type 1 error in this context would mean that the policy makers concluded that there was evidence that there is a difference in proportions of males and females who bring a bag when in fact there isn't. A type 2 error in this context would mean that the policy makers concluded that there was not sufficient evidence that there is a difference in proportions of males and females who bring a bag when in fact there is. The consequences of a type 1 error in this scenario could be that policy makers keep this provision when in fact it is doing more harm to the gameday experience than not having it. The consequences of a type 2 error in this scenario could be that policy makers get rid of this provision when in fact it is helping attendees have a better gameday experience, which could hurt future sales of tickets.

An example of a hypothesis test is if we are trying to find out if a new medication is more effective than an old one before it is made available to the public. The null hypothesis would be that there is no difference between the improvement of patients that took the new drug and patients that took the old drug. The alternative hypothesis is that the difference between the improvement of patients that took the new drug and patients that took the old drug is greater than 0. A type 1 error, or a false positive, would be that we find that the new drug is more effective than the old drug, when it actually isn't. The potential consequences of this is that patients put on the new drug may not see any benefit or may even be harmed. A type 2 error, or a false negative, would be that we find that the new medicine is not more effective than the old medicine, when it actually is. The potential consequences of this is that we keep patients on the old drug when they could be seeing more improvement from the new drug.

Example: Lab 6.1 & 6.3, Activity 2
"Does the data suggest that the survival rate differs when comparing 'banded' to 'non banded' penguins?"

H0: p1 = p2; Ha: p1 does not = p2

A type 1 error in this context would be claiming that survival rates do differ between banded and non banded penguins, when in fact the survival rates do not differ. 

A type 2 error in this context would be claiming that survival rates do not differ between banded and non banded penguins, when in fact the survival rates do differ. 

Consequences from the type 1 error could be creating a problem regarding penguins survival rates that never existed in the first place. Consequences from the type 2 error could be that penguins survival rates may severely decrease because the data would show that there is no problem to worry about when there actually is.

The example used during one of our lectures was that of the judicial system. With this example the null would be "innocent until proven guilty" and the alternative would then be "guilty". When using this example, the type 1 error (false positive) would mean convicting an innocent person of a crime they did not commit (reject null) and the type 2 error (false negative) would mean letting a guilty person walk free (fail to reject null when null is false). The consequences of a type 1 error would be that an innocent person would be in jail and the consequence of a type 2 error would be that a guilty person walks free.

Example: Testing to see if a new drug with potentially harmful side effects  to see if it is significantly better than the drug currently in use. If it is found to be effective it will be given to millions of people 

Null hypothesis: p1=p2
Alternative: p1>p2

If a type 1 error occurred than it would be determined that the new medicine was more effective, even though it was not.
If a type 2 error occurred it would be determined that the new medicine was not more effective than the old medicine even thought it was. 

Making a type one error would be harmful in this case because if it is determined that the medicine is effective it will be given to millions of people. The new medicine has a lot of side affects that could be potentially harmful, so if it was not more effective it would be given to people and could cause them to experience side effects for no reason.

In the example of producing a drug to lower a fever, the null hypothesis would be fever with no treatment=fever with treatment, while the alternative hypothesis would be fever with no treatment<fever with treatment.

A type 1 error would falsely identify the drug as effective(rejecting the null hypothesis when it is true in reality).
A type 2 error would falsely identify the drug as ineffective(accepting the null when the alternative is true).

The consequences of a type 1 error would be falsely prescribing an ineffective drug to patients causing unneeded side effects.
The consequences of a type 2 error would be not prescribing the drug for patients and missing out on its benefits.

"Is the average hours of sleep per night for college students less than 7?"

1. 
HO (null): mu = 7
HA (alt):  mu < 7

The null hypothesis is used for if the average hours slept per night for college students is less than 7. The alternative hypothesis is used for if the statement provided is true.

2. A type 1 error occurs when we reject the null hypothesis, but the statement is true. In this case it would be something like "we conclude that the average hours slept per night for college students is exactly 7, when in reality is is actually less than 7."

3. A type 2 errors occurs when we fail to reject the null hypothesis and the statement is false. In this case it would be something like "we conclude that the average hours slept per night for college students is less than 7, when in reality it is exaclty 7."

4. The consequences can be dire for getting these errors, especially when they occur in the real world.

Medical testing for a disease:
null says patient doesn't have the disease, alternative says patient does have the disease. Type 1 error occurs when the test incorrectly indicates the patient has a disease when in reality they do not(reject null when alternative is false), and a Type 2 occurs when the test incorrectly states the patient does not have the disease when in reality they do (fail to reject null, should have rejected null). A type 1 error would be better off in this case, although not ideal and the only consequence would be brief until it is determined shortly after that it was a false positive, while the Type 2 error in this case is much worse as the person goes on with their life thinking they are disease free when in reality they suffer from it.

You are testing for a genetic disease in parents, then null would be that the parents are carriers and the alternative is that parents are not carriers. 

The type one error would be that the test says that the parents are carriers when they are not. 

The type two error would say that the parents are not carriers when they are not. 

In the case of a type 1 error, the parents may choose to not have children or try to isolate the gene causing the defect despite the fact they are not carriers, wasting their time and money, or causing them to not have kids. In the case of a type 2 error, the parents may choose to have kids believing they do not carry any genes with genetic defeats, this could potentially lead to a child with a life long diseases or disability that could have been avoided. 

In this case a type 2 error would be incredibly harmful to the potential child and parents, while a type 1 error would be less harmful but would be heartbreaking and not true.

My example is a hypothesis test about the effectiveness of a new medication. The null hypothesis is Ho: p1 - p2 = 0, and the alternative is Ha: p1 - p2 > 0 where p1 is the results of people without the medication, and p2 is the results with the medication. A higher result means the medication is effective. A type 1 error, or a false positive, would represent if the medication was deemed effective, when in reality it's not. A type 2 error, or a false negative, would represent if the medication was deemed ineffective, when in reality it is. A type 1 error in this case could result in people taking an ineffective medication that could potentially cause side effects while gaining no benefit from it. A type 2 error in this case could result in people rejecting a medication that could actually help the population of people that need it.

Let's use the example of does the newness of the Mario Kart Wii game affect its price.


The null hypothesis is μ new=μ old. The mean price of the new version of Mario Kart Wii is equal to the mean price of the older version.

The alternate hypothesis is μ new does not equal μ old (the line with the crosses through it)

​


Type 1 Error (False Positive):
Making a Type 1 error in this context would mean incorrectly concluding that there is a difference in the mean prices of the new and older versions when, in reality, there is no such difference. It's a false positive, suggesting an effect of newness on price when there isn't one.

Type 2 Error (False Negative):
Making a Type 2 error would involve failing to detect a real difference in the mean prices of the new and older versions. It's a false negative, indicating that we miss the actual influence of newness on pricing.

Consequences:

Type 1 Error (False Positive):

Consequence: Implementing changes or strategies based on a perceived difference in prices when there isn't one.
Risk: Wasting resources on unnecessary adaptations or marketing efforts.
Type 2 Error (False Negative):

Consequence: Failing to recognize an actual difference in prices between new and older versions.
Risk: Missing opportunities for targeted marketing or pricing adjustments, potentially resulting in lost revenue.

1. The situation described was within an analogy to U.S. criminal law: a person is innocent until proven guilty. The null hypothesis would be the person being innocent, while the alternative hypothesis is the person being proven guilty 
2. A type 1 error is a "false positive", meaning the null hypothesis is rejected when it is actually true or you believe something is true when it isn't. This would be convicting an innocent person - meaning they were innocent but punished anyways. 
3. A type 2 error is a "false negative", meaning there is a failure to reject the null when it is false or you miss something that is true. This would be releasing a guilty person - meaning they did something wrong but were still set free. 
4. With a type 1 error, there is a consequence that you say there is an effect when there actually isn't. With a type 2 error, you are missing out on seeing something that is actually true or there.

An example was in Lab 4.1 in Activity 3 from the following example: Is the average hours of sleep per night for college students less than 7? 
The null hypothesis in this example was the mean or mu equals 7, meaning that in the proposed null hypothesis the college students are getting 7 hours of sleep per night.
Meanwhile, in the alternative hypothesis it states mean or mu is less than 7 hours. In the question above it states is the average 7 or less than 7, so in the alternative hypothesis we are assuming the college students are getting less than 7 hours of sleep per night. 

The meaning of a type 1 error in this example would be rejecting the null hypothesis. Meaning that college students do not get 7 hours of sleep and accepting the alternative hypothesis, that college students get less than 7 hours of sleep per night, when actually it is true college students get 7 hours of sleep per night.

The meaning of a type 2 error in this example would be failing to reject the null hypothesis that college students get 7 hours of sleep per night, when they actually get less than 7 hours of sleep per night.

Some consequences associated with the type 1 error would be that college students would sleep more, which in the end would cause health problems or school problems from sleeping too much. The opposite would happen for a type 2 error, college students would not get enough sleep and it would impact their health and their ability to complete schoolwork.

Null Hypothesis: The new drug has no effect on reducing blood pressure.
Alternative Hypothesis: The new drug is effective in reducing blood pressure.

Type 1 Error (False Positive):

In this context, a Type 1 error occurs if we reject the null hypothesis when it is true. It means concluding that the new drug is effective in reducing blood pressure when, in reality, it has no such effect. The consequence of a Type 1 error could lead to the pharmaceutical company investing resources in producing and marketing a drug that does not provide the claimed benefit, potentially harming patients and wasting resources.

Type 2 Error (False Negative):

A Type 2 error occurs when we fail to reject the null hypothesis when the alternative is true. In the context of the blood pressure drug, it means not recognizing the drug's effectiveness when it actually has the desired effect. The consequence of a Type 2 error could be missed opportunities for patients to receive a potentially beneficial treatment, leading to ongoing health issues and missed advancements in medical care.

Consequences of Wrong Decisions:

Type 1 Error: Misleadingly concluding that the drug is effective may result in unnecessary costs, potential side effects for patients, and damage to the company's reputation.
Type 2 Error: Failing to recognize the drug's effectiveness could lead to missed health benefits, delayed medical advancements, and continued reliance on less effective treatments. Patients may suffer from avoidable health issues due to the failure to adopt an efficacious drug.

Null Hypothesis: The new online teaching method has no effect on students' mathematics performance compared to traditional classroom teaching.
Alternative Hypothesis: The new online teaching method improves students' mathematics performance compared to traditional classroom teaching.

A Type 1 error would occur if the study concludes that the new online teaching method improves mathematics performance and reject the null.

A Type 2 error would happen if the study fails to detect the improvement in mathematics performance due to the new online method and do not reject null.

Consequences: 
Making a Type 1 error might lead to the widespread adoption of an ineffective teaching method, resulting in wasted resources, potential declines in overall educational quality, and misplaced confidence in the new method.

If a Type 2 error is made, a beneficial teaching method might be disregarded. This could mean missed opportunities for improving student learning outcomes, and the educational system may continue using less effective methods without exploring potential advancements.

- A type I error is when the null hypothesis is rejected, but it is true. In this context, that would mean we reject the null hypothesis and conclude that the mean score for the intervention group is significantly higher than the mean score for the control group on the HRSIW subset, when we shouldn't have.

- A type II error occurs when one fails to reject a null hypothesis that is false. In this context, that would mean that we do not reject the null that the mean score for the intervention group on the HRSIW subtest is not significantly different from the mean score for the control group when we should have.

- Null hypothesis (H0): The patient does not have the disease and alternative hypothesis (H1): The patient has the disease.

- A Type 1 error in this context would occur if the test incorrectly indicates that a patient has the disease (rejecting the null hypothesis) when, in reality, they do not. This is a "false positive" result

- A Type 2 error would happen if the test fails to detect the disease (fails to reject the null hypothesis) when the patient actually has it. This is a "false negative" result. 

- Type 1 Error could lead to unnecessary treatments, stress, and financial costs for patients who are actually healthy while type 2 error could cause delayed treatment, potential complications, and worsening health for patients who actually have the disease.

1. The example from class that I chose was "a person is innocent until proven guilty"; is the evidence stronger than any doubt? The null hypothesis for this example would be H0: p=0. The alternative hypothesis would be Ha: p>0. 
2. A type 1 error (false positive) happens when you reject a null that is actually true; you think you have evidence for the alternative, but you do not. For the chosen example, a type 1 error would happen if an innocent person was convicted. 
3. A type 2 error (false negative) happens when you do not reject a null even though it is false; you do not think you have evidence for the alternative, but you actually do. In this example, a type 2 error would happen if you release a person who is guilty. 
4. There are obvious consequences for type 1 and 2 errors. In this example, the type 1 error would accuse the wrong (innocent) person, and make them face the consequences of something they did not do. This would also lead to the type 2 error of releasing the person who is actually guilty. This is obviously a bad thing because they are being let off the hook for something they did wrong and not having to face the consequences.

The null hypothesis (H0) could be that the new drug has no effect, while the alternative hypothesis (H1) posits that the new drug is effective.

Null Hypothesis (H0): The new drug has no effect.

Alternative Hypothesis (H1): The new drug is effective.

Type 1 Error (False Positive): In this context, a Type 1 error would occur if the hypothesis test incorrectly concludes that the new drug is effective when, in reality, it has no effect. This could lead the pharmaceutical company to invest in further development, production, and marketing of a drug that does not provide any real benefits.

Type 2 Error (False Negative): A Type 2 error would happen if the test fails to detect the effectiveness of the new drug when it does, in fact, have a positive impact. This could result in the company missing out on a potentially valuable drug, leading to lost opportunities for both the company and patients.

Consequences of Type 1 Error: The consequences of a Type 1 error include wasted resources, financial losses, and potentially exposing patients to a drug with no real benefits or even adverse effects.

Consequences of Type 2 Error: The consequences of a Type 2 error involve missed opportunities for a pharmaceutical company to bring a beneficial drug to market. Patients may suffer from untreated conditions, and the company may lose out on potential profits and reputation gains.

In the context of the pharmaceutical industry, the decisions made based on hypothesis testing can have significant real-world implications for both the company and the well-being of patients. Balancing the risks of Type 1 and Type 2 errors is crucial in making informed decisions about drug efficacy and development.

Null and Alternative Hypotheses:
Null Hypothesis (H0): The new drug is not effective in treating the condition.
Alternative Hypothesis (H1): The new drug is effective in treating the condition.

Type I Error (False Positive):
In this context, a Type I error would occur if we conclude that the new drug is effective when it actually is not. This error leads us to wrongly reject the null hypothesis.

Type II Error (False Negative):
A Type II error would happen if we conclude that the drug is not effective when, in fact, it is. This error results in incorrectly accepting the null hypothesis.

Consequences of Each Error:
Type I Error Consequences: Approving an ineffective drug could lead to patients using a treatment that does not work, potentially causing them to miss out on more effective treatments. It could also lead to unnecessary side effects and waste of resources.

Type II Error Consequences: If a beneficial drug is deemed ineffective, patients miss out on a potentially helpful treatment. Additionally, the scientific and medical communities lose valuable findings, and the development of effective treatments for the condition could be delayed.

An example related to a clinical trial for a new drug:

Null Hypothesis: The new drug has no effect, and there is no difference in outcomes between the treatment group and the control group.

Alternative Hypothesis: The new drug has a significant effect, and there is a difference in outcomes between the treatment group and the control group.

Type 1 Error (False Positive): In the context of the drug trial, a Type 1 error occurs if the analysis incorrectly rejects the null hypothesis, indicating that the drug has a significant effect when, in reality, it does not. This could lead to the adoption of an ineffective or potentially harmful drug.

Type 2 Error (False Negative): A Type 2 error in this scenario would happen if the analysis fails to reject the null hypothesis, suggesting that the drug has no effect when, in fact, it does. This could result in the rejection of a genuinely beneficial drug.

Consequences of Type 1 Error: Approving a drug that is actually ineffective or harmful may expose patients to unnecessary risks and side effects, and healthcare resources might be misallocated.

Consequences of Type 2 Error: Failing to approve a drug that is genuinely effective could deny patients access to a beneficial treatment, potentially leading to worsened health outcomes and missed opportunities for medical advancement.

Lets say researchers want to test if a new vaccine increases white blood cells or not. The null hypothesis would be that the medicine does not increase white blood cells while the alternative hypothesis would be the medicine does increase white blood cells. 

After completing their research they find that the p-value is significant and therefore they reject the null and say they found sufficient evidence that the medicine does increase white blood cells. While this could be the case, whenever you reject the null there is always a possibility that you are creating a type 1 error. This means that you have rejected the null and said there is an effect but in reality the null was true and nothing actually happened. 

On the other hand lets imagine they found the p-value to be not significant and they do not reject the null. This means that they are saying they did not find enough evidence to prove the medicine increased white blood cells. When you do not reject the null there is always a chance that the alternative hypothesis was true and this is known as a type 2 error. In this case the vaccine does increase white blood cells but you said it did not. 

Whatever decision you make there is always a chance of error but you have to decide which one is better. Let's say the vaccine is super dangerous and can be really harmful to people so we want to make absolute certain that we are correct when we say it increases white blood cells before administering it. To make sure we aren't putting people in danger when there is no benefit we would want to avoid a type 1 error so we would reduce the significance level to 1% (or less). 

Now the consequences of making a type 2 error is that you say the vaccine wasn't helpful and didn't increase white blood cells when in reality it did and you could have saved millions of people.

- The null hypothesis is the statement or claim being made, which we are trying to disprove. The alternative hypothesis is the hypothesis that we are trying to prove and which we will not reject if we have enough evidence to reject the null hypothesis. 

- Type 1 occurs when we reject the null hypothesis when it's actually true (false positive). 
- Type 2 error occurs when we fail to reject the null hypothesis when it's false (false negative). 

- Both errors have significant consequences, for type 1, incorrect assumptions can lose time and resources, while type 2 can result in a missed opportunity.

4. If we committed a type 1 error in this context, it would mean that we told others that Vitamin D indeed provides protection against Multiple sclerosis, when it really does not. If people worried about getting MS begin taking vitamin D, they would be doing so in vain, as it is no use. If we committed a type 2 error in this context, it would mean that we told people that Vitamin D does NOT provide any protection against Multiple sclerosis, although it actually does. This may be a worse consequence, because those worried about getting MS may not take vitamin D to curb their chances, when in reality, it would be very helpful to do so.

The alternative hypothesis is that there is a significant increase in the arousal of men when looking at a woman on a red background versus looking at a woman on a different colored background. Type 1 error would be if the report stated that there was a significant difference in men's arousal when there was no difference. Type 2 error would be if the report stated that there was no significant difference when there was a significant difference. A consequence associated with the type 1 and type 2 errors could be wasted resources on advertising.

(H0): p=0.20

Type 1 Error would occur when it is concluded that option B is more likely to be correct when, in reality, there is no significant difference in the likelihood of all options.

Type 2 Error would happen if when it is failed to detect that option B is more likely to be correct when, in fact, it is.

Consequences of Type 1 Error: If a Type 1 error occurs, and it is incorrectly concluded that option B is more likely to be correct, it may lead to biased test strategies. This could result in potential disadvantages for students on the actual exams.

Consequences of Type 2 Error: If a Type 2 error occurs, and the test fails to detect that option B is more likely to be correct, students might not receive the correct guidance on effective test-taking strategies. This could lead to a negative impact on the performance of AP exams.

The null is always equal to zero or another number in the data, where the alternative hypothesis can be greater than, less than, or not equal to zero or another number in the data. A type 1 error is a false positive error so if something is said to be right but is in fact not. A type 2 error is a false negative meaning that whatever is said is wrong but the opposite it correct. Type 1 error you are making a wrong assumption and can lose time and resources. Type 2 errors can result in a missed opportunity to change or enhance a project.

Example: Based on the p-value of 0.212 for the one-sided alternative hypothesis about the linear association between systolic blood pressure (mm Hg) and heart rate (beats/minute) in the population, what would the correct formal conclusion be if we were testing a two-sided hypothesis with the same sample?

1. 
Null Hypothesis: There is no linear association between systolic blood pressure and heart rate in the population.
Alternative Hypothesis: There is a positive linear association between systolic blood pressure and heart rate in the population.

2. 
A Type I error would occur if you incorrectly reject the null hypothesis and conclude that there is a linear association between systolic blood pressure and heart rate when there actually is none. This would be a false positive. 

A Type II error would occur if you incorrectly fail to reject the null hypothesis when there actually is a linear association between systolic blood pressure and heart rate. This would be a false negative.

3.
Type I Error (False Positive): Concluding that there is a significant linear association when there isn't could lead to unnecessary interventions or treatments. For example, unnecessary medical interventions might be implemented when there is no real correlation between systolic blood pressure and heart rate.

Type II Error (False Negative): Failing to detect a real linear association could lead to a lack of necessary interventions or treatments. For example, not identifying a genuine correlation between systolic blood pressure and heart rate could potentially harm one's medical care.

Example: Are body length and head length related in possums?
The null hypothesis is that body length and head length are not related: there is no correlation.
The alternative hypothesis is that there is a correlation: that body and head length are related.
In this case, a false positive (type 1 error) would mean that while a correlation was found, body length and head length were not actually related.
In this case, a false negative (type 2 error) would mean that while no correlation was found, body length and head length were actually related.
In either error case a false conclusion would be drawn: for type 1 a false conclusion of effect, and for type 2 a false conclusion of lack of effect.

Using an example from the 4.1 lab. "We are interested in testing to see if there is evidence that the correlation between exam grades (in percentages) and hours spent playing video games is negative for a population of students."
Null Hypothesis: There is no proof that there is a negative correlation, or any link at all, between exam scores and the amount of time spent playing video games.

Alternative hypothesis: There is evidence of a negative correlation between exam scores and the amount of time spent playing video games, indicating that higher exam scores are linked to greater gaming time.
Type 1 Error (False Positive): In this case, a Type 1 error would occur if we incorrectly concluded that exam scores and video game hours are negatively correlated while, there is no such association. The result could be giving children false advice to cut back on video game time in an attempt to raise their grades when there isn't really a connection, which could lead to unneeded stress or behavioral changes.

Type 2 Error (False Negative): If we are unable to find a true negative association, it is likely that playing more video games has an impact on exam scores. The result could be that students miss out on the chance to identify a possible cause affecting their exam scores and don't get useful advice on how to balance their activities for more accurate results. 

While a Type 2 error would indicate failing to see a true association between video game playing and test performance, a Type 1 error could result in unneeded modifications based on a false correlation. Finding an appropriate balance is crucial to preventing students from feeling unnecessary anxiety and making sure that any relevant problems affecting grades are properly handled.

A type 2 error is when you fail to reject the null hypothesis, when it is false. Type 1 errors make incorrect inferences and type 2 errors can affect the outcomes of a test.

Let us examine a scenario in which a pharmaceutical company is conducting a trial to determine the effectiveness of a novel medication.
Null Hypothesis (H0): There is no discernible difference in the outcomes of the treated and untreated groups, and the new medication has no effect.
Alternative Hypothesis (H1):The new medication has a notable impact, and the treated and untreated groups' outcomes differ.
Type 1 Error (False Positive):When a study determines that a new drug is effective when it is not, that is a Type 1 error. This can result in the pharmaceutical corporation spending money producing and marketing a medication that doesn't offer the promised advantages.The result is the expenditure of time, money, and resources on the creation and marketing of a medication that is not really effective, which could cause financial losses for the pharmaceutical company and, more importantly, expose patients to a course of treatment that has no real advantages or even negative side effects. 
Type 2 Error (False Negative):If the new drug's true effectiveness is not detected in the trial, and it is assumed that there is no substantial effect when in fact there is, this is known as a Type 2 error. This could result in a potentially helpful medication being rejected, harming patients and missing out on chances to develop medicine.The outcome is the medicine that could have had a lot of advantages being rejected. This could lead to lost chances to enhance patient outcomes, postpone the delivery of a necessary treatment, and possibly injure patients by preventing them from getting a helpful drug.

null: p1 = p2  alt: p1 does not = p2

-Let's use a pharmaceutical business testing the effectiveness of a new medicine as an example. The alternative hypothesis (H1) contends that the medication is effective, while the null hypothesis (H0) claims the treatment has no effect.
-In this case, the corporation would make a Type I error (false positive) if it incorrectly determines that the medication is effective and has no therapeutic value. This might result in the drug being made available on the market before it should, endangering people.
-On the other hand, if the drug's actual effectiveness is not identified when it has positive effects, this could result in a Type II error, also known as a false negative. This could lead to a potentially advantageous medication being rejected, depriving patients of a favorable course of treatment.
-Type I and Type II errors have severe repercussions in this pharmaceutical scenario. A Type I error could result in the provision of a dangerous or ineffective medication, which could hurt public health. Conversely, a Type II error can lead to the withholding of a helpful medication, depriving patients of a treatment that could save or improve their lives. It is essential to strike the correct balance when doing hypothesis testing to prevent these unfavorable effects and make wise judgments for the public's health and safety.

In a law system where a person is innocent until proven guilty, the null hypothesis would state that the person is innocent. The alternative hypothesis would state that the person is guilty. This error would mean that an innocent person was imprisoned. A Type II error would indicate that a guilty person was not found guilty (the null hypothesis is not rejected when it should have been). This error would mean that a criminal is not punished.

The example I choose was from the 6.1 and 6.3 lab activities. In the lab it talked about the the use of metal tabs on king penguins flippers that track climate change and whether or not these tabs had an effect on these penguins breeding success as well as survival rates. In this example the null hypothesis is "the use of flipper bands does not have significant effect on the survival rate of king penguins" and the alternative hypothesis is "the use of flipper bands does have significant effect on the survival rate of king penguins" 

A type 1 error would mean that the conclusion was made that the use of flippers bands has a significant effect on the survival rates and breeding success of king penguins when in reality there is no effect. 

A type 2 error would be vis-versus. It means that there was a failure to detect a significant effect of flipper bands on king penguins survival rates and breeding success when this effect actually does exist. 

The consequences of these errors may be large. In a type 1 error unnecessary change may be implemented which would be a waste of resources and could actually leave the penguins worse off as well as their ecosystem. On the other hand, In a type 2 error a real effect may not be recognized leading to a lack of measures on changing the bands for the penguin. This could lead to harm to the penguins and a decline in their population.  

The lab question is implemented below. 
"Penguins are excellent indicators of the state of health of marine ecosystems and thus make it possible to better understand the impact of climate change on biodiversity. Until now, most of the available data has been obtained by banding the penguin with a metal tag on the flipper so that data can be obtained from a distance. However, the use of flipper bands does raise serious questions as they can have deleterious effects on the penguins which include injuring flipper tissues or increasing energy expenditure while swimming or fishing due to the hydrodynamic drag effect on the flippers that the penguins use to propel themselves. Such long-term practices could harm penguin populations which are already under threat from other environmental factors.

This is the first study where one hundred king penguins had electronic tags implanted under their skin. By random assignment, half were also fitted with a flipper band such that 50 were banded and 50 were not banded. Over a ten-year period, differences in both survival rate and reproduction (breeding success) were examined when comparing the two groups. We will consider survival rates in this lab."

1Saraux, C., et al., “Reliability of flipper-banded penguins as indicators of climate change,” Nature, January 2011; 469: 203–206.

The alternative hypothesis stated a significant difference or effect, suggesting that the test results are indicative of the presence or absence of the disease.

Type 1 Error (False Positive):
In the context of the medical test, a Type 1 error would occur if the null hypothesis is incorrectly rejected when it is actually true. This would mean the test wrongly indicates the presence of the disease when the individual is actually healthy. This is a false positive result.

Type 2 Error (False Negative):
A Type 2 error would occur if the null hypothesis is not rejected when it is false. This would mean the test fails to detect the presence of the disease when the individual is, in fact, affected. This is a false negative result.

Consequences of Errors:
Type 1 Error (False Positive): The consequence of a false positive. It may also lead to unnecessary treatment, which could have potential side effects.

Type 2 Error (False Negative): A false negative could have severe consequences. It might result in individuals with the disease not receiving timely treatment, allowing the disease to progress unchecked, leading to more severe health issues.
