"Research with humans and other animals suggests that walking benefits physical health. Because of these findings, it has been suggested that walking is important to elephant welfare, and that zoo elephant exhibits should be designed to allow for more walking.  This study used anklets equipped with GPS data loggers to measure outdoor daily walking distance/day (in kilometers) in 56 adult female elephants housed in 30 North American zoos. There were 33 African elephants and 23 Asian elephants. Is there a difference in the average distance travel/day when comparing the African to the Asian elephant?"

The null hypothesis would be that there is no difference in the average distance travel/day when comparing the African to the Asian elephant.
The alternative would be that there is a difference in the average distance travel/day when comparing the African to the Asian elephant.
A type 1 error is thinking that there was a difference when there really was not. A consequence of this would be that one group of elephants may be pushed to exercise more than they have to which may make them overly tired.  
A type 2 error is thinking that there was no difference when there really was. A consequence of this would be having a group of elephants not exercise enough which would continue to have them be unhealthy.

Researchers are testing an experimental drug called Compound V (CV), that is made to reduce sore throats in times of illness. Researchers bring in a simple random sample of 50 men, all with sore throats to test the drug on. They prepare the CV in the same bottles as the placebo, and the order in which they administer the bottles are random. All cases get both the CV and the placebo in random order without the researchers knowledge of the order (double blind experiment). The researchers want to find whether the Compound V works just beyond 50% efficacy rate, so they test if it cures 70% of patients or more. They set the alpha level at 5% (0.05).

Null hypothesis: p = 0.5
Alternative hypothesis: p >/= 0.7

A type 1 error would mean a false positive, in other words the researchers think the CV works more than 70% of the time when in reality it doesn't.

A type 2 error would mean a false negative, in other words the researchers fail to reject the null, when in reality they should have because the CV has an efficacy rate of 70% or higher.

The consequence of a type 2 error would be worse in this scenario because if the medicine really does work 70% of the time or greater, you would want that on the shelves over a product that only works half of the time. If they make a type 2 error, they might go back to he lab and change the formula, possibly ruining the 70% efficacy rate they once had.

A new medicine for kidney stones is being tested to determine if it really lowers the amount of kidney stones someone has. Two groups are compared with one group using the medicine and the second group using a placebo.

Ho: p1-p2=0
Ha: p1-p2< 0

A type one error would be that we reject the null hypothesis to determine that the drug is effective at reducing kidney stones when it really had no impact.

A type two error would be that we fail to reject the null hypothesis determining that the drug has no effect on reducing kidney stones when the drug is actually effective.

These errors could result in consequences such as missing out on the opportunity to use an effective drug because we believe it doesn't work when it really does.

For drug testing, a null hypothesis might be that the drug has no effect compared to a control, and the alternative hypothesis would be that the drug does have a particular effect compared to the control.

A type 1 error would be that the null hypothesis was mistakenly rejected. In this case, that would mean that the medication had an effect, but the researchers found it to be ineffective.

A type 2 error would be that the null hypothesis was not rejected by mistake. In this case, that would mean that the medication had no effect, but the researchers found it to be effective.

As a consequence of these error people might be prescribed ineffective drugs, or might not be prescribed drugs that are effective.

The example I am using is "does the proportion of people who support gun control differ between males and females?" The null hypotheses is that there is no difference between males and females in terms of supporting gun control. The alternative hypotheses is that there is a difference between males and females supporting gun control. A type 1 error would occur if we incorrectly reject the null hypothesis, suggesting that there is a significant difference between males and females supporting gun control, when it reality the null was right in the sense that there is no difference between the two genders supporting gun control. A type 2 error would occur if we fail to reject the null hypothesis, suggesting that there is no significant difference between males and females supporting gun control, when in reality the alternative is correct in the sense there is a real difference between males and females supporting gun control. Making a Type 1 error in this context of gun control could lead to unwarranted policy or social interventions based on a perceived gender difference that doesn't actually exist. It might result in implementing measures targeted at a specific gender when, in fact, there is no true difference. Making a Type 2 error could have consequences such as overlooking a genuine gender difference in support for gun control. This might lead to a failure to implement necessary policies or interventions addressing actual disparities in attitudes toward gun control between males and females.

“Let's consider an example involving a drug trial where the null hypothesis states that the new medication has no effect on reducing blood pressure, while the alternative hypothesis suggests that the drug significantly lowers blood pressure.”

Null Hypothesis: The new medication has no significant effect on reducing blood pressure.
Alternative Hypothesis:The new medication significantly lowers blood pressure.

Type 1 Error (False Positive):a type 1 error would occur if the study concludes that the medication significantly reduces blood pressure (rejecting the null hypothesis) when, in reality, the drug has no effect. The consequence could be endorsing a medication that doesn't truly help, leading to unnecessary costs and possible side effects in the medication.

-Type 2 Error (False Negative):A type 2 error would happen if the study fails to detect a significant reduction in blood pressure when the drug actually does have an effect. The consequence could be the rejection of a potentially beneficial treatment, resulting in untreated health issues.

The null hypothesis (H0) would be that the new drug is no more effective than the current standard treatment in lowering blood pressure. The alternative hypothesis (H1) would be that the new drug is more effective than the current standard treatment.
A Type I error, or a "false positive," in this context would mean concluding that the new drug is more effective when in reality, it is not. Essentially, it's incorrectly rejecting the null hypothesis.
A Type II error, or a "false negative," would mean failing to recognize the new drug's effectiveness, concluding that it is not better than the standard treatment when it actually is. This error occurs when the null hypothesis is incorrectly accepted.
The potential consequences of a Type I error might include wasting resources on producing and marketing a new drug that is not actually better, as well as patients potentially experiencing unnecessary side effects from a medication that is not more effective than their usual treatment.
The potential consequences of a Type II error could be missing out on a better treatment for patients that could improve their health outcomes, as well as a loss of potential profits and advancements in medicine for the pharmaceutical company.

Consequense for type 1 error is if the null hypothesis is false, it may be more difficult to reject using a low value for α. We could end up with a type 2 error. Consequences of type 2 error is that if the null hypothesis is true, increasing α makes it more likely that we commit a Type I error.

One example we discussed in class asked us about whether young adults want to spend more minutes talking with their parents when they are thinking about mortality as opposed to dental pain. Our null hypothesis was Ho: p1 - p2 = 0 and our alternative hypothesis was Ha: p1 - p2 > 0. In this context, a type 1 error would mean we reject the null even though it is true (we conclude that young adults DO want to spend more time talking to their parents after thinking about death even though they DO NOT). Oppositely, a type 2 error would mean we do not reject the null even though it is false (we conclude that young adults DO NOT want to talk to their parents more after thinking about death even though they DO). Since this study does not focus on some sort of life or death experiment (for instance, administering a drug that could either kill you or save you), the consequences for making these errors would not be detrimental, but simply make you wrong in your conclusions.

Type I: the pill has an effect, but is concluded it does not.

Let's say there's a new blood pressure drug. The null hypothesis is that it doesn't work, and the alternative is that it does. Making a Type I error (a false positive) would mean approving a drug that doesn't actually work, costing money and causing side effects. A Type II error (a false negative) would be missing a drug that could really help, leading to delayed treatment and possible health issues.

In a medical trial evaluating a new drug's efficacy, the null hypothesis assumes no effect, the alternative hypothesis posits the drug's effectiveness, a type 1 error entails incorrectly claiming efficacy when absent, and a type 2 error involves failing to detect efficacy when present, with potential consequences of endorsing an ineffective treatment or overlooking a beneficial one.

Null Hypothesis (H0): There is no difference in the desire of young adults to spend more minutes talking with their parents when thinking about mortality compared to dental pain (μ=mortality = μ=dental pain).
Alternative Hypothesis (Ha): Young adults want to spend more minutes talking with their parents when thinking about mortality compared to dental pain (μ=mortality > μ=dental pain).

Meaning: Rejecting the null hypothesis when it is actually true.
Context: A Type 1 error in this context occurs if researchers incorrectly conclude that young adults prefer more minutes of conversation about mortality when, in reality, there is no significant difference. 

Meaning: Failing to reject the null hypothesis when the alternative hypothesis is true.
Context: A Type 2 error occurs if researchers fail to detect a genuine preference among young adults for more minutes of conversation about mortality compared to dental pain. 

Type 1 Error: The potential consequence is implementing unnecessary interventions or policies based on the assumption of a preference for discussing mortality, leading to misallocation of resources and potential discomfort for young adults.
Type 2 Error: The potential consequence is neglecting a true preference among young adults for discussing mortality, resulting in missed opportunities for providing support or initiating meaningful conversations during times of contemplation about life and death.

Example: Testing a New Drug for Treating a Disease

Null Hypothesis (H0): The new drug has no effect on treating the disease, meaning its efficacy is the same as the placebo.
Alternative Hypothesis (H1): The new drug is effective in treating the disease, meaning it has a different efficacy than the placebo.

Type 1 Error (False Positive): This error would occur if we conclude that the new drug is effective when it is not. In this context, a Type 1 error means we mistakenly believe the drug works against the disease when it actually does not have a significant therapeutic effect. The consequences of this error could include patients being exposed to an ineffective treatment, potential side effects, and unnecessary healthcare costs.

Type 2 Error (False Negative): This error happens if we conclude that the new drug is not effective when it actually is. In this scenario, a Type 2 error means failing to recognize the genuine efficacy of the drug. The consequences could be missing out on a beneficial treatment for patients, continued use of less effective treatments, and a delay in the adoption of a more effective therapy.

In summary, while a Type 1 error leads to the adoption of a useless or potentially harmful treatment, a Type 2 error results in overlooking a beneficial treatment. Both errors have significant implications in healthcare decisions, affecting patient outcomes and resource allocation.

EXAMPLE: testing new drug with potentially dangerous side effects to see if it is better than the drug in current use. 
null hypothesis: effectiveness of new drug=old drug
alternative: effectiveness of new drug>effectiveness of old drug
Making a type 1 error would be finding evidence that the drug is effective when it is actually ineffective. Making a type 2 error would be determining a drug is ineffective when it is actually effective. If you make a type 1 error, individuals will be prescribed the drug and not see results needed by the medication, while also being exposed to dangerous side effects. If you make a type 2 error this medication will not be prescribed, although it has the potential to make in impact as it is an effective medication.

Null and Alternative Hypotheses:
Null Hypothesis (H0): The new drug is no more effective than the current standard treatment.
Alternative Hypothesis (H1): The new drug is more effective than the current standard treatment.
Type I Error (False Positive):
In this context, a Type I error occurs if we incorrectly reject the null hypothesis and conclude that the new drug is more effective when it actually is not.
This might happen if, due to random sample variation, the test group taking the new drug shows better outcomes than the control group, even though the drug is not truly more effective.
Type II Error (False Negative):
A Type II error occurs if we incorrectly fail to reject the null hypothesis, concluding that the new drug is not more effective than the standard treatment when it actually is.
This error might happen if the sample size is too small or the effect of the drug is not strong enough to be detected by the test, leading us to miss a genuine improvement over the standard treatment.
Consequences:
Consequences of a Type I Error: Unnecessarily switching to or promoting a new drug that is no more effective than the standard, potentially wasting resources and giving patients false hope.
Consequences of a Type II Error: Missing out on a better treatment option, continuing to use a less effective standard treatment, and thus not providing patients with the most effective care.

In one of the examples, we were trying to figure out if the true population mean of annual rainfall was less than 40 inches. The null would be m=40 and the alternative would be m < 40. A type 1 error would be a false positive meaning that we would falsely reject the null. We would say that m <40 when it is either equal to or greater than 40. A type 2 error would be a false negative meaning that we would falsely fail to reject the null. We would say that m = 40 when in reality is is less than 40. A type 1 error could lead to believing rainfall is less than it usually is which could lead to flooding or overwatering of crops. A type 2 error would lead to believing that there is more rainfall which could lead to crops being underwatered and even death of crops.

The medicine may not have any noticeable effects, according to the null hypothesis, but it may be effective, according to the alternative hypothesis. When a medication is prescribed when it isn't beneficial, this is known as a Type 1 error, or false positive, and it can result in needless treatments and related hazards. On the other hand, a Type 2 error, sometimes known as a false negative, occurs when the drug's true effectiveness is disregarded, leaving conditions untreated and advantages to health unrealized. Finding the right balance in decision-making is essential since mistakes made in any direction can have a big impact on patient care, costs, and resource distribution.

In a lab question, we were testing a new drug with potentially dangerous side effects to see if it is significantly better than the drug currently in use. If it is found to be more effective, it will be prescribed to millions of people. The null hypothesis would be that the new drug is less effective than the old drug. The alternative hypothesis would be that the new drug is more effective than the old drug. A type one error will occur when you conclude that the new drug is more affective than than the old drug, but actually is not. A type two error will occur when you conclude that the new drug is less effective than the old drug, but it actually is. A potential consequence of the type 1 error would be if people use the new drug instead of the old one when it is not actually going to help. A type 2 error would be is people use the old drug instead of the new one when the new one is actually better.

Null Hypothesis (H₀): The manufacturing process produces products with no defects.
Alternative Hypothesis (H₁): The manufacturing process produces products with defects.

Type I Error (False Positive):
A Type I error in this context would occur if the quality control test incorrectly rejects the null hypothesis, indicating that there are defects in the products when, in reality, there are none. This "false positive" could lead to unnecessary halting of production, additional expenses for reevaluation, and disruptions in the manufacturing process.

Type II Error (False Negative):
Conversely, a Type II error would occur if the test fails to reject the null hypothesis when it is false, indicating that the products are defect-free when, in fact, they have defects. This "false negative" could result in defective products reaching the market, potentially leading to customer dissatisfaction, product recalls, and damage to the company's reputation.

Type I Error (False Positive): Unnecessary production halts, increased costs, and disruptions in the manufacturing process due to incorrectly identifying defects that do not exist.
Type II Error (False Negative): Defective products reaching consumers, potential harm to the company's reputation, customer dissatisfaction, and possible recalls.

In describing type 1 and 2 errors, we used a law analogy. Since I am a pre-law student, it has stuck with me. A type 1 error is when we reject the null hypothesis, but the null ends up being true. A type 2 error is when we fail to reject the null hypothesis, and the null ends up being false. In the chosen context, a type one error would be that we rejected the null that men and women go equally, but in reality, this is true. A type two error would be that we fail to reject the null that women and men go equally, and we accept this as fact, but in reality, men go more often on average than women. 

Consequences for type one is a false positive, which means that we are led to false beliefs about the data. The same goes for type two. Regardless, we are believing the wrong explanation about the data.

Eg: A medical lab assistant is testing that medication 1 has less effect than medication 2.

- Null Hypothesis: both have same effect
  Alternative Hypothesis: medication 2 has more effect than medication 1.

- Type 1 error: When we conclude that medication 2 has more effect than medication 1 while they both have the same effect.

- Type 2 error: When we conclude that they both have the same effect while truly medication 2 has more effect than medication 1.

- Consequences of Type 1 error: wasted resources, financial losses, and potential harm if the medication 2 is distributed.

Consequences of Type 2 error: missed opportunities for improving health, as medication 2 might be overlooked, impacting patients who could benefit from it.

Example: A company wants to test if their cream reduces knee pain. 
Null Hypothesis: It has no effect compared to its placebo
Alternative Hypothesis: The cream successfully reduces knee pain.
Type 1 Error: The company concludes the cream has no effect when in reality it does.
Type 2 Error: The company concludes the cream does have an effect when in fact it doesn't.

Potential Consequences: In the type 1 error the company doesn't release its product and nothing of significance happens. In the type 2 error, the company releases the cream and people realize their claims of pain relief were a lie.

I chose the question "Does the proportion of people who support gun control differ between males and females?". The null hypothesis for this question would be H0: p1 - p2 = 0 and the alternative hypothesis would be Ha: p1 - p2 ≠ 0. The null implies that there is no difference between the proportions of male and female gun support and the alternative implies that there is a difference between the proportions of male and female gun support. A type one error would be if we rejected the null hypothesis that there is no difference between the proportions of male and female gun support when there really is no difference. A type two error would be if we did not reject the null hypothesis that there is no difference between the proportions of male and female gun support when there really is a difference between those proportions. The consequences of both type one and type two errors in this scenario would be that the results of the test are inaccurate and that incorrect assumptions were made about the proportion of male and female gun support

The null hypothesis asks what the data will show if the variables have no effect on the outcome of the other. So, in the medicine example, the null hypothesis would state that the medicine has no effect on whoever takes it. The alternative hypothesis, on the other hand, illustrates what the effect of the variable will be, if any. So, in this case, it would be that the medicine has an effect in improving some symptoms. A type 1 error is when you reject the null hypothesis, and conclude that the alternative is correct, when in fact, it is not. A type 2 error, on the other hand, is when you fail to reject the null, and do not make conclusions on the data, when in fact, the null is incorrect. The potential consequences with each of these is that, in the case of the medicine, if we believed that it worked when it really doesn't, people are wasting money and could be putting themselves in danger. On the other hand, if people do not believe the medicine works when it really does, people could be improving their health, but they aren't.

Type 1 error: Young adults want to talk more with their parents after thinking about mortality, when really they don't.
Type 2 error: Young adults do not want to talk more with their parents after thinking about mortality, when really they do.

People will believe that young adults don't want to talk more to their parents when thinking about mortality when really they do.

Example: See whether or not 60% of residents will vote yes on a bill.
1) Null: population mean (mu) = .60
     Alt: pop. mean (mu) does not equal .60
2) A type I error means that we concluded that the % of residents who voted yes does not equal 60 (.60), when in actuality it does. 
3) A type II error means that we concluded exactly 60% of residents voted yes, when actually either more or less than 60% did.
4) Both can lead us to make conclusions that do not accurately represent the population.

The example I chose is the researcher is trying to figure out if the majority of a STAT 200 class has a GPA over 3.0. The null hypothesis is 50% of the class has a GPA over 3.0. The alternative hypothesis is that more than half of the class has a higher GPA.  A type one error would be that we find the null hypothesis is false when it actually is true. A type two error would be that we found the alternative hypothesis is wrong when in reality its true. The potential consequence of a type one error is that we have now reported that more than half of our class has a high GPA when in reality, it is lower. A consequence of the alternative hypothesis is that we have found that half of the class or lower has a high GPA, when it is way more than that, which means we could possible be teaching the class in a different way.

A type 1 error in this context would mean wrongly concluding that the drug has a positive effect when it actually doesn't. This could lead to the drug being approved and administered widely despite its inefficacy, wasting resources and potentially causing harm.

Conversely, a type 2 error would occur if the study fails to detect the actual effectiveness of the drug, leading to the conclusion that it's not effective when it truly is. This might result in the rejection or shelving of a potentially beneficial treatment, impacting patient outcomes and healthcare advancements.

In both cases, there are significant real-world implications: Type 1 errors may lead to unnecessary adoption of ineffective treatments, while type 2 errors might prevent the adoption of beneficial interventions, impacting patient care and medical advancements.

Researches are trying to test out a drug called OxiMax to see if it cures muscle cramping.
 Null: Oximax does not cure muscle cramps.
Alternative: Oximax cures muscle cramps.

Type 1: It is concluded that the drug does not cure muscle cramps even though it does.
A potential consequence is not providing people with the correct medication.

Type 2: It is concluded that the drug does cure muscle samples even though it doesn't.
A potential consequence is medicating people with a placebo.

The null hypothesis is that there is no difference between a group receiving the drug and a group receiving the placebo. The alternative hypothesis is that the group receiving the drug has effects that the placebo group does not get. A type 1 error would occur if the researchers incorrectly reject the null hypothesis. A type 2 error would occur if the researchers rejected the null, when it should not be rejected. The consequences that could occur would be unnecessary treatments being done (type 1) or failure to adopt new treatment (type 2).

This is the research question for the example I have chosen: Our goal is to show that young adults want to spend more minutes talking with their parents when they are thinking about mortality as opposed to dental pain.

The null hypothesis for this study is Ho=Mu1=Mu2. and the alternative hypothesis for this study is Ha: Mu1>Mu2. These would be the hypotheses because they describe the average minutes (numerical) and the population parameter for that is Mu. The null hypothesis would be that the two groups are equal because that shows no change and the alternative would be that group 1 spends more time than group 2, thus it would be a greater than symbol.

In this context, a type 1 error (false positive) would show that young adults do want to spend more time with their parents when talking about morality as opposed to dental pain, when in reality they do not, or there is no difference between the groups. In this context, a type 2 error (false negative) would show that young adults do not want to spend more time with parents when talking about morality vs dental pain when in reality they do. With each type of error made, there could be many potential consequences associated with each type of wrong decision. For instance, if a type 1 error is made, parents will feel that their kids will only want to spend more time with them when they are in pain. Where as if a type 2 error is made a consequence could be parents not talking about deep things with their children, like morality, and only thinking their child needs them when they are in pain.

1. The null hypothesis is a statement that there is no significant difference, effect, or relationship between two or more variables or groups being studied. The alternative hypothesis  is a statement that contradicts the null hypothesis
2.  Rejecting the null hypothesis when it is actually true.
3. Failing to reject the null hypothesis when it is actually false.
4.  Type 1 Example: Concluding that a new drug is effective when it has no real impact.
Implication: Patients might be exposed to unnecessary treatments, and resources could be misallocated based on a false belief in the presence of an effect.
Type 2 Example: Failing to detect that a new drug is effective when it could provide significant benefits.
Implication: Patients may miss out on a treatment that could improve their health, and resources might not be directed toward genuinely effective interventions.

1. The null hypothesis is what the researcher is trying to disprove. The alternative hypothesis is what the researcher is trying to prove. 
2. A type 1 error is when you think something is working but it really isn't doing anything
3. A type 2 error is when you think something doesn't work but it actually does and you might need it.

An example used in this class was whether male students on campus had a higher incidence of going to the gym when compared to female students. 

The null hypothesis here is that there is no difference between the two groups and that they have equal proportions of going to the gym. 

The alternative hypothesis is that male students have a higher proportion of going to the gym when compared to female students. 

A type one error here would be to reject the null and conclude that male students indeed have a higher occurrence of going to the gym when the null is correct and there is no difference between the two groups. 

A type two error would be to fail to reject the null and conclude that there was no difference between the two groups when in reality male students have a higher occurrence of going to the gym when compared to female students.

Making a type one error would lead to incorrectly label one group as going to the gym more frequently and claiming there is a difference where there is not one. A type two error would  then be misinterpreting the results that show that the alternative is correct, ignoring significant conclusions.

Question: Does the proportion of people who support gun control differ between males and females? 
Ho: The proportion of people supporting gun control in Group 1 (males) is equal to the proportion in Group 2 (females) - p1=p2 
Ha: The proportion of people supporting gun control in Group 1 (males) is different from the proportion in Group 2 (females) - p1 (does not equal) p2 

Type 1 Error: Incorrectly concluding that there is a difference in the proportions when, in reality, there is no difference (false positive).

Type 2 Error: Incorrectly concluding that there is no difference in the proportions when, in reality, there is a difference (false negative).

Type 1 Error: Incorrectly concluding that there is a difference in the proportions when there isn't (false positive) could lead to the implementation of unnecessary policies or interventions targeting gender differences in gun control support.

Type 2 Error: Incorrectly concluding that there is no difference in the proportions when there is one (false negative) might result in overlooking actual gender differences in gun control support, leading to a failure to implement needed measures or interventions.

The example I have decided to use is pregnancy, in which the null hypothesis would be Ho = 0, meaning that the woman is not pregnant.  The alternative hypothesis would be Ha ≠ 0, meaning that the woman is pregnant.  The meaning of a type 1 error for this example would be that you reject the null, but the null is actually true, so that would be like saying the woman is pregnant, when in reality she isn't.  The meaning of a type 2 error for this example would be that you do not reject the null, and the null turns out to be false, so that would be saying that we assume the woman is not pregnant when in actuality she is pregnant.  The consequences associated with a type 1 error is this context would be thinking you are pregnant, when you actually aren't.  Conversely, the consequences of making a type 2 error in this context would be thinking that you are not pregnant when you actually are pregnant.  So with the described example, a type 2 error would certainly be worse in this context.
